Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Okay, lets tackle this problem step by step. First, I need to understand what the Procure-to-Pay (P2P) process normally entails. From what I remember, the standard steps are: 1. Create Purchase Requisition 2. Approve Purchase Requisition 3. Issue Purchase Order (PO) 4. Receive Goods 5. Receive Vendor Invoice 6. Match Invoice to PO (and possibly Goods Receipt) 7. Release Payment 8. Close Case So the typical flow is sequential with approvals and checks along the way. Any deviation from this order might indicate an anomaly.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Starting with Case 1001. The activities are in the order: Create, Approve, Issue, Receive Goods, Invoice Received, Match, Payment, Close. That all looks correct. Each step follows logically. No issues here.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Now Case 1002. Lets list their activities in order: - Create Purchase Requisition - Issue Purchase Order (after 10 minutes) - Vendor Invoice Received (next day) - Release Payment (15 minutes after invoice) - Approve Purchase Requisition (later the same day) - Receive Goods (next day) - Match Invoice to PO (two days after payment) - Close Case Wait, this is out of order.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The main problem here is that the Purchase Order was issued before the requisition was approved. Normally, a requisition needs approval before moving to creating a PO. So they issued the PO without approval. Also, the payment was released before the requisition was approved and before the goods were received. Thats a big red flag. How can they pay the invoice before even getting the goods? Also, invoice matching is done after payment, which should be done before releasing payment to ensure the invoice matches the PO and goods received. So thats definitely an anomaly.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Case 1003: Activities: - Create, Approve, Issue PO (all in order on the same day) - Then Release Payment (a week later) - Then Invoice Received (next day after payment) - Receive Goods (next day after invoice) - Match Invoice (after goods received) - Close Here, payment is released before the invoice is received and before goods are received.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Thats problematic. You cant pay an invoice you havent received yet. Also, goods received after payment is unusual. Normally, you receive goods first, then receive the invoice, match them, then pay. So this case has payment before invoice and goods, which is out of order.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Case 1004: Activities: - Create, Approve (same day) - Then Receive Goods (next day) - Issue Purchase Order (15 minutes after receiving goods) - Invoice Received (next day) - Match Invoice to PO, Release Payment, then Close Wait, they received goods before issuing the PO?

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: That doesnt make sense. How can you receive goods without a PO? The PO is sent to the vendor, who then delivers the goods. Receiving goods before PO issuance implies they accepted delivery without a PO, which could mean unauthorized purchases. Then they issued the PO afterward, which is backwards. Also, the invoice is received after goods, which is okay, but the PO was issued after receiving goods, which is problematic. The sequence here is Create, Approve, Receive Goods, Issue PO, which is out of order. The PO should come after approval and before receiving goods.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So the anomalies are in Cases 1002, 1003, and 1004. Each has different issues. Let me summarize each cases issues. Case 1002: PO issued before requisition approval, payment released before approval, goods received, and invoice matching. Also, the requisition was approved after the payment was made, which is a control issue. So approvals should happen before any financial commitments. Case 1003: Payment released before receiving the invoice and goods. How did they know how much to pay? The invoice comes after payment, which is not standard. Also, goods received after payment is not typical. You receive goods, then process the invoice, match, then pay. Case 1004: Goods received before issuing the PO. This is a major control failure. The PO is a commitment to pay, so receiving goods without a PO could lead to unauthorized expenditures. Then issuing a PO after receiving goods is putting the cart before the horseâ€”POs should authorize the vendor to deliver.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: These anomalies are problematic because they bypass controls meant to prevent fraud, errors, or mismanagement. For example, paying before approval or without matching could lead to paying incorrect amounts or paying for goods not received. Receiving goods without a PO could mean accepting unauthorized deliveries, leading to inventory discrepancies or financial losses. I should make sure I didnt miss any other cases. Case 1001 is normal. All others have issues. Let me check 1004 again. Their sequence after receiving goods is: Issue PO, then invoice received, then match. But normally, the PO is sent to the vendor to deliver goods, so the vendor sends the goods along with the invoice. If the PO was issued after receiving goods, how did the vendor know to send the goods? Unless its a case where they created the PO after the fact, which is bad practice. So each of these anomalies can lead to financial risks, compliance issues, or operational inefficiencies.
